Award.AwardTitle: WiFiUS: Device-to-Device Communications at Millimeter-Wave Frequencies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The dramatic increase in traffic - both aggregate, and peak traffic per user - will soon outpace the capabilities of current cellular systems like LTE. To cope with the increased requirements, new systems need to be developed that both exploit the use of new spectrum, and new radio access methods. An especially promising method with those features is device-to-device (D2D) communications operating at millimeter-wave frequencies. D2D communications exploits the fact that in many situations, such as in social networks, two devices that want to communicate are in close proximity to each other. While such devices could talk to each other via infrastructure nodes, it is much more spectrally efficient to enable direct communications between the devices, especially for inter-device distances much smaller than the cell radius; this also enables higher data rates. Further data rate increases can be obtained by exploiting the large swatch of new spectrum in the millimeter-wave frequency bands. The use of millimeter-wave frequencies for WiFi-like systems is has already been standardized and first products are reaching the market. Furthermore, millimeter-wave links are now also considered for wireless access, i.e., connection from a mobile cellphone to a base station or access point. Recently, cellphone manufacturers have demonstrated prototypes of handsets with millimeter-wave transceivers and adaptive antennas, showing the practical viability for mobile applications. This opens up the possibilities for millimeter-wave based D2D systems as well.

This project will investigate fundamental questions of realizing D2D communications at millimeter-wave frequencies. Critically, such systems are not simply "regular D2D systems operating at higher frequencies"; rather, new and important challenges arise in the context of channel modeling, link setup, link adaptation, and robustness. To solve these, we tackle the following 4 main challenges: (i) measurement of D2D propagation channels at mm-wave frequencies, using innovative measurement techniques and evaluations such as laser-scanning based ray tracing; (ii) neighbor discovery, i.e., finding which devices can talk to each other, taking into account the directional nature of the device antennas; (iii) dynamic beamforming and beamtracking, which integrates a key property of millimeter-wave channels that the directions of the strongest multipath components can change rapidly; and (iv) capacity and reliability investigations. Results from this project will form the basis for systems that support wireless high-speed connections, as are relevant for video conferences, real-time gaming, situational awareness, and many others. Equally importantly, by offloading resource-consuming connections, cellular resources are freed up for other applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Answering the increasing demand for wireless data and enabling new use cases are two of the key requirements for the next generation wireless networks. Utilizing new frequency band (millimeter-wave (mmWave) band), adopting large scale multi-antenna systems, and enabling direct device-to-device (D2D) communications are among the main suggested solutions to these requirements. Understanding the properties of the communication channels in these systems are of prime importance for setting up efficient standards and designing reliable communication systems. The main goals of this project were to provide accurate characterization to propagation channels that will be used in future wireless systems, and tackle some of the key enabling solutions to these systems.

  • Channel Modeling: The vast majority of current wireless systems use a single frequency band (at centimeter wave (cmWave) frequencies). However,  due to the harsh propagation conditions at high frequencies, and for backward system compatibility, it is expected that the mmWave frequencies are going to be deployed alongside the cmWave band in future wireless networks. Initial investigations of channel properties over different frequency bands reveal considerable correlation, thus for complete channel characterizations and to better utilization of large existing systems and literature, it is important to understand the congruence between the two bands. To do that, in this project, we assemble a dual-band channel sounder system to record the channel states in cmWave frequency (ranging from 2-6 GHz), and the mmWave frequency (between 59-63 GHz). For comparability of results, the measurement campaigns were carried out such that measurement points are at the exact same locations for both cmWave and mmWave bands.

The trends and the relations in the extracted parameters are studied in different domains and under different scenarios to capture the underlying channel models, important ??condensed?? parameters, relative systems performance, and the correlation over the two frequency bands. Further datasets were obtained in collaboration with our Finnish partners (at Aalto University) from a so-called ?point cloud? simulator, which is based on a high-resolution laser scan of the same environment. The overall result of these efforts are multi-band channel models that allow system designers to find new methods of how to exploit the fact that propagation at different bands is correlated but not identical. This in turn improves data throughput, reliability, and energy efficiency of wireless communications, not only in the research items of this project, but also for other researchers.

 

  • D2D Neighbor discovery: Neighbor discovery is a prerequisite for D2D communication, devices must exchange signals to verify their neighbor relations. In such networks, devices could have access to prior information about their possible set of neighbors, e.g., through the assistance of the base station (BS) or prior discoveries in dual-band systems. In this project, we provided efficient randomized and deterministic schemes for the neighbor discovery which help to speed up the neighbor discovery, thus decreasing transmission latency, and allowing faster adaptation to a changing environment.

 

  • Band Assignment in dual-band systems: The susceptibility of mmWave frequency to blockage makes the realization of mobile communication in mmWave challenging. Switching between different frequency bands could alleviate this; and the BS might need to assign the mobile station (MS) to one of the two bands. In this project, we proposed several schemes to address this problem. In two analytical solutions, we used observed channel state information and known correlation models to predict the best frequency band. However, such schemes rely on several channel assumptions that might not hold in all scenarios. We alternatively, proposed solutions based on Machine Learning (ML) models. The ML-based solutions can utilize several types of observations and rely on minimal channel assumptions, this resulted in evident performance gain in different scenarios and under different types of observations.

 

  • Hybrid Multi-input-multi-output (MIMO): To combat the severe path loss and small scale fading in high frequencies, mmWave systems are expected to utilize large MIMO systems, thus devices can concentrate their communication toward certain directions (i.e., perform beamforming). However, using a large number of independent antennas (by using RF chain for every antenna) is prohibitive in practice due to cost and power constraints. Hybrid system designs reduce the number of relative RF chains and thus can use digital beamforming in the baseband, and analog beamforming in the RF. In this project, we addressed several aspects of beamforming in hybrid MIMO, where we provided optimal and low complexity beamforming techniques that rely on instantaneous and long-term CSI. These technologies can be especially important if massive MIMO to be adopted in D2D systems.
